content: The Act titled "Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007" or "K.T. Safety Act of 2007" mandates the consideration of rulemaking for power windows on motor vehicles to automatically reverse direction when detecting an obstruction to enhance child safety. The Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007 mandates safety standards for power windows and panels to detect obstructions and prevent accidents. The Secretary must decide on these standards within 30 months of the Act's enactment. The Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007 requires safety standards for power windows and panels to prevent accidents. Within 30 months of the Act's enactment, a report must be transmitted to the House and Senate committees explaining why the standards were not prescribed. Information on vehicles equipped with power windows that automatically reverse direction when an obstruction is detected must be made public. The Secretary will revise FMVSS 111 to expand rearward visibility for drivers to detect areas behind vehicles, reducing accidents involving small children and disabled persons. Different requirements may be set for various vehicle types. The Secretary will revise FMVSS 111 to expand rearward visibility for drivers using additional mirrors, sensors, cameras, or technology to reduce accidents involving small children and disabled persons. Final standards must be prescribed within 36 months of the Act's enactment, with a phase-in period required for compliance. The Secretary will establish a phase-in period for compliance with rearward visibility safety standards, with full compliance required within 48 months of the final rule issuance. Different types of motor vehicles may have varying phase-in priorities based on backing incident data. Vehicles involved in backing incidents causing injury or death may be prioritized by the Secretary for phased-in regulations. Motor vehicles with automatic transmission manufactured after September 1, 2010, must have a system to prevent rolling away. After September 1, 2010, vehicles with automatic transmission must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". Violations will be treated as a safety standard violation and enforced by the Secretary. Each motor vehicle manufacturer must submit information on noncompliant vehicles with automatic transmissions to the Secretary. The Secretary will publish this information for public access within 30 days of receiving it. The Act requires the publication of non-compliant motor vehicle make and model information to the public. Vehicles not listed are presumed to comply with safety standards. The definition of a motor vehicle excludes certain types as per title 49, United States Code. The Act mandates the publication of non-compliant motor vehicle details to the public, with vehicles not listed presumed to meet safety standards. The definition of a motor vehicle excludes motorcycles, trailers, and those rated over 10,000 pounds. Additionally, a database on injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles must be established within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The database established under the Act includes information on injuries and deaths from specified events, vehicle details, and other relevant variables. The Secretary is required to make this information available to the public. The Secretary must implement a child safety information program within 9 months of the Act's enactment. This program will address hazards to children in nontraffic, noncrash incidents by either enhancing an existing consumer information program or creating a new one. The Secretary will use collected data to prioritize safety measures. The Secretary will establish priorities for a child safety information program, address various risks to children, and make program information available to the public.
